definition: to stir up trouble/to invite disaster
to provoke/to irritate/to vex/to stir up/to anger/to attract (troubles)/to cause (problems)
disaster/misfortune/calamity
to invite disaster

sentences.english: This child is always making trouble for his parents.
sentences.chinese: 這孩子老給父母招災惹禍。

sentences.english: Bring misfortune of recruit son, terrified don't want.
sentences.chinese: 惹禍的招子，怕別想要了。

sentences.english: There once was a lady who was very concerned about heer missing parrot.
sentences.chinese: 曾經有一個女士非常關心她惹禍的鸚鵡。

sentences.english: Sometimes I would tap their hands when they made troubles.
sentences.chinese: 當他們惹禍時，有時候我會輕拍他們的手。

sentences.english: Giving certain gifts could get you in trouble.
sentences.chinese: 送禮不當可能會使你惹禍上身。

sentences.english: If you steal, you'll be in trouble. You'll be arrested.
sentences.chinese: 你偷東西就會惹禍，你會被抓起來。

definition: ill-gotten wealth or gains

timely/at the right moment/appropriate to the occasion/opportune/to fit current fashion
to mention sth without elaborating (idiom); not giving details
to arouse dislike/to incur hatred
imprisonment
to console
lit. to punch and kick (idiom); to beat up/fig. determined to sort out a problem
to lose one's job/unemployment/not to fulfill one's obligations/to neglect one's job/dereliction of duty
to set a trap
shameful secret
a thousand pounds hangs by a thread (idiom)/imminent peril/a matter of life or death

avaricious and insatiable (idiom); greedy and never satisfied
to think for oneself and act accordingly (idiom); to act on one's own initiative
to condemn in speech and in writing (idiom)/to denounce by word and pen
